docs.abstract: When movies and shows from “Blindspotting” to “Detroit” wrestle with the emotional toll of violence against black people, their creators’ intentions matter.
docs.snippet: When movies and shows from “Blindspotting” to “Detroit” wrestle with the emotional toll of violence against black people, their creators’ intentions matter.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the stylish comedy-drama “Blindspotting,” Collin (Daveed Diggs), a felon with three days left of probation, is the only eyewitness to the shooting of a young black man by a white police officer. Collin, stopped at a traffic light, locks eyes with the officer, but once additional officers arrive, they demand he leave immediately. He tries to forget the event and carry on (as he reasons, he can’t call 911 and say, “I’d like to report a murder you just did”), but Collin is haunted by what he saw.

headline.main: Fictional Police Brutality, Real Emotional Toll
headline.print_headline: Police Violence and Its Toll, Onscreen

docs.abstract: The music mogul is an executive producer of a sprawling six-part docu-series centered on the death of Mr. Martin, and the divisive verdict.
docs.snippet: The music mogul is an executive producer of a sprawling six-part docu-series centered on the death of Mr. Martin, and the divisive verdict.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the six-part docu-series “Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story,” the filmmakers Jenner Furst and Julia Willoughby Nason recount the teenager’s life and his deadly encounter with George Zimmerman in a gated townhouse community outside Orlando. Through interviews with key players, including Mr. Martin’s family and Don West, a defense lawyer for Mr. Zimmerman, the directors zero in on what they see as a flawed criminal justice system. They also make an argument that the divisive case (in which Mr. Zimmerman was acquitted of second-degree murder and manslaughter) galvanized both the Black Lives Matter movement and white nationalists.

headline.main: Jay-Z on ‘Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story’ and Activism

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story (TV Program)

docs.abstract: Can you remove a color from an entire city? Michael Rakowitz is trying, and is asking Clevelanders to participate in his community-based art project.
docs.snippet: Can you remove a color from an entire city? Michael Rakowitz is trying, and is asking Clevelanders to participate in his community-based art project.
docs.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Boxes of pizza and trays filled with steaming food lined wooden tables at the Spaces art gallery here. Visitors to a recent opening could help themselves, but if they chose corn on the cob or chicken nuggets, they had to reach over the sign that read: “Please enjoy this offering of Tamir Rice’s favorite foods, to make him present in a project that is about his death.”

headline.main: An Artist Honors Tamir Rice, One Orange Object at a Time
headline.print_headline: One Artist’s Singular Mission, and Palette

docs.abstract: Four years after Mr. Garner’s death, police officials said on Thursday they were beginning disciplinary proceedings against an officer who choked him.
docs.snippet: Four years after Mr. Garner’s death, police officials said on Thursday they were beginning disciplinary proceedings against an officer who choked him.
docs.lead_paragraph: After years of postponing disciplinary proceedings against the officer who choked Eric Garner in 2014, the New York Police Department said on Thursday that it would immediately begin preparing for an internal administrative trial.

headline.main: Police Move to Discipline Officer Involved in Eric Garner’s Death
headline.print_headline: Police Department Moves to Discipline  Officer in Deadly 2014 Chokehold Case

docs.abstract: On the eve of the fourth anniversary of the death of Eric Garner, police officials said they will not wait past Aug. 31 to begin disciplinary hearings.
docs.snippet: On the eve of the fourth anniversary of the death of Eric Garner, police officials said they will not wait past Aug. 31 to begin disciplinary hearings.
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department, impatient at the slow pace of the federal government’s civil rights investigation into the death of Eric Garner in July  2014, told the Justice Department on Monday that it would soon start disciplinary proceedings against the officers involved in the killing in the absence of federal action.

headline.main: Police Dept. Gives Federal Investigators Ultimatum in Eric Garner Case
headline.print_headline: As Federal Inquiry Stalls, N.Y.P.D. Will Proceed With Internal Garner Case

byline.original: By Benjamin Weiser and J. David Goodman

docs.abstract: Aurore Valade’s bright and busy photographs show that resistance can be messy, joyful and sometimes lonely.
docs.snippet: Aurore Valade’s bright and busy photographs show that resistance can be messy, joyful and sometimes lonely.
docs.lead_paragraph: ARLES, France — We live in an age of anger, we are told. It might be more accurate to say that we live in an age of protest. Whether at the Women’s March or defending Black Lives Matter, the March for Our Lives or the rallies in France against the policies of President Emmanuel Macron, a willingness to go into the streets and shout is a defining characteristic of our era.

headline.main: Eye-Popping Portraits for an Age of Protest

docs.abstract: Defiance and justice drive this brisk staging from the Classical Theater of Harlem, directed by Carl Cofield.
docs.snippet: Defiance and justice drive this brisk staging from the Classical Theater of Harlem, directed by Carl Cofield.
docs.lead_paragraph: A makeshift shrine sprawls across the base of an imposing concrete facade — flowers, stuffed animals, deflating balloons, a profusion of glowing candles. The wall is chalked with graffiti, and placards lean against it: “RIP Eteocles,” “say his name,” “black lives matter.”

headline.main: Review: ‘Antigone’ Asserts Whose Lives Matter, With Modern Relevance
headline.print_headline: Want to Defy the King? Be Prepared to Die

docs.abstract: Productions include the filmmaker Todd Solondz’s first play, “Emma and Max,” and Thomas Bradshaw’s incendiary “Southern Promises.”
docs.snippet: Productions include the filmmaker Todd Solondz’s first play, “Emma and Max,” and Thomas Bradshaw’s incendiary “Southern Promises.”
docs.lead_paragraph: The upcoming season of the Flea Theater is not for the faint of heart: productions will tackle police brutality, gun violence, infanticide and slavery, and the often squirm-inducing filmmaker Todd Solondz will make his playwriting and stage directing debut.

headline.main: The Upcoming Flea Season Will Explore Police Brutality and Gun Violence
headline.print_headline: Flea Theater Announces A ‘Color Brave’ Season

docs.abstract: The Times’s assistant TV editor, Aisha Harris, discusses how representations of police brutality in media have changed. She says shows like “Insecure” and “Queen Sugar” sensitively deal with this issue by focusing on the interactions’ emotional toll, not the violence itself.
docs.snippet: The Times’s assistant TV editor, Aisha Harris, discusses how representations of police brutality in media have changed. She says shows like “Insecure” and “Queen Sugar” sensitively deal with this issue by focusing on the interactions’ emotional to...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Times’s assistant TV editor, Aisha Harris, discusses how representations of police brutality in media have changed. She says shows like “Insecure” and “Queen Sugar” sensitively deal with this issue by focusing on the interactions’ emotional toll, not the violence itself.

headline.main: Police Violence is Flooding Our Screens. What’s the Impact?

byline.original: By Aisha Harris, Ainara Tiefenthäler, Natalie Reneau and Maea Lenei Buhre
